Actinomadura meyerae is a species of actinobacteria that was first isolated from a soil sample collected in Brazil. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium that belongs to the genus Actinomadura.

The cells of A. meyerae are typically rod-shaped and can form branched hyphae. The colony morphology on agar plates is typically powdery or chalky in appearance, with a range of colors from white to pinkish-red.

Phylogenetically, A. meyerae is closely related to other Actinomadura species and is classified within the family Thermomonosporaceae. The species was named in honor of the microbiologist Johanna Mayer, who made significant contributions to the taxonomy of actinobacteria.

A. meyerae is considered a soil-dwelling bacterium and has been found in various terrestrial environments. The species is known to possess the ability to degrade complex organic compounds, making it a potential candidate for bioremediation applications.

Further research on the physiological, metabolic, and ecological characteristics of A. meyerae may provide insights into its role in the natural environment and potential biotechnological applications.
